Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Visual Analytics for Ontology Matching

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Ontologies are developed to provide semantics for a particular domain and to support information retrieval, reasoning and knowledge discovery. However, as separate groups develop ontologies, there is a need to combine or match ontologies to support connecting information across heterogeneous sources. Ontology matching is a complicated process that stems from the need to involve several types of matching algorithms that take into account syntactic, lexical, structural, instance, and logic features of the ontologies. The current support provided to users to understand and evaluate the results provided by ontology matching systems is very limited; therefore ontology matching is an arduous and time consuming task. This exploratory project focuses on development of a novel approach to ontology matching that employs visual analytics to guide the users in the process. It is expected to result in increased quality of resulting ontologies while also reducing the time and effort of experts involved in ontology matching.

Visual analytics is at the confluence of information visualization, data analytics, and data transformation. This project explores the potential of visual analytics to effectively assist real-time decisions by domain experts and ontology researchers alike during the ontology matching process. The project is organized around three key research challenges:
(1) Visualization: Data and analytically extracted features need to be encoded into rich visualizations that can be effectively manipulated. In particular, visualizations should lend themselves well to complex transformations that facilitate the discernment of trends or patterns.
(2) Architecture: The interaction between the automatic matching and the visual analytics modules is central to the proposed approach. The envisioned architecture will support a quality-controlled feedback loop in which users will intervene to change the analytic and visual parameters of the system.
(3) Performance evaluation: Performance measures will be developed to objectively identify the obtained gains in terms of the effort saved by users and of the quality of the matching results as enabled by the proposed visual analytics approach to ontology matching.

If successful, this proof-of-concept project is expected to make a significant contribution in effective ontology matching that in turn will enable semantically enriched access to complex, heterogeneous, and distributed data to an increasing number of users in a variety of domains. Research results, including developed software, will be made available via the project web site (http://agreementmaker.org/wiki/index.php/Visual_Analytics). The project provides research experience to students and results from this research will be included in the computer science curriculum.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the data science era, data integration is a fundamental capability, which allows for the uniform access to heterogeneous, independently created data sources. A major component of data integration is the ability to match logically organized concepts, which describe the organization of each data source, in the form of an ontology (e.g., a taxonomy). However, ontology matching is a complicated process that involves several types of algorithms (namely syntactic, lexical, structural, instance-based, and logic). For these reasons, ontology matching is both a complex and time consuming task, which requires automation to unburden users (including domain experts and ontology researchers) but which should be able to accept users’ input when the automated process is not sufficient. This exploratory project focuses on the development of a novel approach to ontology matching that employs visual analytics---a combination of information visualization and data analytics---to effectively assist real-time decisions by users. The project’s contributions are organized around three key research challenges:

(1) Visualization: Data and analytically extracted features need to be encoded into rich visualizations that can be effectively manipulated. In particular, visualizations should lend themselves well to complex transformations that facilitate the discernment of trends or patterns.

(2) Architecture: The interaction between the automatic matching and the visual analytics modules is central to the proposed approach. The envisioned architecture will support a quality-controlled feedback loop in which users intervene to validate (or invalidate) mappings that were found automatically.

(3) Performance: The evaluation of the performance encompasses several aspects, from the effectiveness of the automatic methods to the quantification of the effort that is saved in terms of the number of validations required from users, or the quality of the matching results when a visual analytics approach to ontology matching is followed.

We have published our results in venues associated with a wide range of communities: the Database/Semantics Community (ODBASE), the Semantic Web Community (ISWC, ESWC, EKAW), the Life Sciences Community (International Conference on Data Integration in the Life Sciences), the AI community (Artificial Intelligence Review), the GIS community (ACM SIGSPATIAL GIS and GIR), the Information Visualization community (InfoVis), and the biomedical community (PLoS ONE).

Regarding broader impacts, related topics have been included in the teaching of a graduate course on "Data and Web Semantics", which has been taught yearly, with end of the term projects on ontology matching and visualization. Students in the new senior/graduate course "Introduction to Data Science" (taught for the first time at UIC in Spring 2016) were taught principles of data integration and ontology matching. Students were also introduced to the user interfaces for ontology matching that support visual analytics developed under this project. Fifteen students including ten women (graduate and undergraduate) were directly involved in this project. The open source distribution of AgreementMaker (with already dozens of users prior to the open source release, including national labs and many academic labs) and AgreementMakerLight (in collaboration with the University of Lisbon) have contributed to the technology transfer of the research results obtained under this project. We note that first AgreementMaker and more recently AgreementMakerLight have been top performers at the Ontology Alignment Evaluation Initiative (OAEI) since 2009, in a field that has become more competitive every year: in 2015 there were 22 participants vs. 14 participants in 2014.
